ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Bilateral SNHL with significant asymmetry and recent decline in the right ear; acoustic reflexes and negative MRI support cochlear site of lesion.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Retrocochlear pathology
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to asymmetric thresholds and significant decline in word recognition, but ruled out by negative MRI.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and configuration, specifically checking for changes since prior annual evaluation.
To assess word recognition ability, particularly to quantify the reported difficulty and check for retrocochlear signs.
To screen for retrocochlear pathology given the asymmetry.
To verify hearing aid gain against NAL-NL1 targets.
To determine available gain before feedback and assess suitability of coupling (domes vs molds).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Annual evaluation revealed a significant decline in hearing sensitivity and word recognition in the right ear compared to the previous year, creating an asymmetry. Acoustic reflexes were normal, suggesting cochlear involvement, but the changes warranted medical referral.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Asymmetric SNHL; Right ear showed 15 dB decline at 1000 Hz and 10 dB at 2000 Hz compared to prior year.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear WRS decreased significantly from 92% to 76%; Left ear stable.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Thresholds and decay within normal limits at 500 and 1000 Hz.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial hearing aid fitting with open domes. Verification showed insufficient gain in the high frequencies due to feedback limitations, confirming the need for better ear coupling.

tests.name: Real Ear Measures
tests.result_summary: REIG was 10 to 15 dB below NAL-NL1 targets between 3000 and 4000 Hz due to feedback.

tests.name: Feedback test
tests.result_summary: Showed limited available gain prior to feedback with open domes.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Follow-up fitting with custom silicone earmolds. The better seal allowed for increased gain, successfully matching prescriptive targets without feedback, and the patient reported improved comfort.

tests.name: Real Ear Measures
tests.result_summary: REIG matched NAL-NL1 targets in the 3000-4000 Hz range.

tests.name: Feedback test
tests.result_summary: Revealed significantly greater available gain compared to the open dome fitting.

proposed_items: Fit with bilateral Widex Clear 440-F RIC hearing aids
counseling_actions: Discussed advantages and disadvantages of domes versus custom earmolds (comfort, retention, feedback)
Counseled on the importance of high-frequency gain (3000-4000 Hz) for speech recognition
Explained that open domes caused feedback and prevented matching gain targets
Recommended medical referral due to significant decline in hearing and WRS

red_flags_present: Significant decrease in word recognition score

escalation.rationale_short: Referral required to rule out retrocochlear pathology given the asymmetric progression and WRS decline (MRI subsequently ordered).

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing thresholds and word recognition scores for further changes and verify continued benefit from amplification.

expected_outcome: Patient reported via an outcome measure that his hearing aids provided significant benefit
Patient was very satisfied with the comfort and retention provided by the custom earmolds
Patient was very pleased with the performance of his hearing aids and remote control
